- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6).

-->

## Steps to reproduce

```
1. Open terminal
2. Enter _pwsh_ to execute powershell
3. Now try to autocomplete some command like _dnf upg_... (I'm using fedora 33) or _flatpak ins_...
```

## Expected behavior

```
I'm using powershell on mac os too and there autocomplete works like a charm.
So I was expecting the exact same behavior on linux.
```

## Actual behavior

```
Autocomplete linux commands are not working. But autocomplete for powershell commands works.
```

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.3
OS                             Linux 5.10.22-200.fc33.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Mar 9 …
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

I have installed pwsh using [official docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/pt-br/powershell/scripting/install/installing-powershell-core-on-linux?view=powershell-7.1#installation-via-package-repository-preferred---fedora-28-29-and-30)

And yes, I know it says fedora 28, 29 and 30 but there's any reason to?

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
You can get tab completion for non-PS commands via @rjmholt's module here: https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/Microsoft.PowerShell.UnixCompleters/0.1.1 We're looking to put this functionality straight into PowerShell at some point, but if you pick that up, you'll get whatever completions are available to bash on that same machine.
Microsoft.PowerShell.UnixCompleters 0.1.1
Get parameter completion for native Unix utilities. Requires zsh or bash.
